creditline: Bequest of Duane E. Wilder, Class of 1951

makers.displaydate: 1946–1989; born Floral Park, NY; died Boston, MA; active New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Robert Mapplethorpe, 1946–1989; born Floral Park, NY; died Boston, MA; active New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: One of the best-known photographers of the 1980s, Mapplethorpe is remembered both for the elegant delineations of his classically informed black-and-white photography and for his representations of sexually explicit homoeroticism and the aesthetics of sadomasochism. Charles Bowman was one of Mapplethorpe’s favorite models. He is shown here as a cropped male torso with a scar just above the pelvis, in an image made six years before the publication of Black Males; this photograph has many of the characteristics that are most admired in Mapplethorpe’s work with the nude form—clarity of composition, a highly polished sense of texture and surface, and the sculptural quality of the abstracted human body—as well as evidencing the problematic ways in which he fetishized the black male body.
texts.remarks: The Eclectic Eye: A Tribute to Duane Wilder

texts.textentryhtml: [Robert Miller Gallery]; acquired by Duane E. Wilder (1929-2017), Class of 1951, December 1988; bequeathed to Princeton University Art Museum, January 2018.
